means: 给（窗户或房间）装上帘子

lj.lj_ly: her decision brought down the curtain on a glittering 30-year career.

derivation.yuyuan_name: Middle English: from Old French cortine, from late Latin cortina, translation of Greek aulaia, from aulē 'court'

entry.def: Curtains are large pieces of material which you hang from the top of a window.
Curtains are pieces of very thin material which you hang in front of windows in order to prevent people from seeing in.
In a theatre, the curtain is the large piece of material that hangs in front of the stage until a performance begins.

example.ex: The curtain rises toward the end of the Prelude.
example.tran: 序曲将近结束时帷幕升起来了。

entry.def: You can refer to something as a curtain when it is thick and difficult to see through or get past.

example.ex: He saw something dark disappear behind the curtain of leaves.
example.tran: 他看到一个黑漆漆的东西从浓密的树叶后消失了。

entry.def: If something brings down the curtain on an event or situation, it causes or marks the end of it.

example.ex: Management changes are under way that will finally bring down the curtain on Lord Forte's extraordinary working life.
example.tran: 正在进行的管理层变更将最终为福特勋爵辉煌的职业生涯画上句号。

means.word_mean: 1. hanging cloth used as a blind (especially for a window)
2. any barrier to communication or vision;

Sentence.sentence: The curtains were never drawn, even at night, so guests got a view of the lake and fountains outside which were lit up at night – a very attractive sight.

jushi.english: The curtain is lowered at the end of each scene.
If you pull the curtain back, people will see in.
jushi.chinese: 如果你把帘子拉开,人们会往里看的。

jushi.english: The curtain divided and the play began.
